text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- Turkmenistan President Saparmurat Niyazov, on a visit to Russia, has managed to make Moscow its ally in a row with Azerbaijan over a disputed oil deposit in the Caspian sea.
- Russian print shops decline orders to print a book by President Boris Yeltsin's former bodyguard Alexander Korzhakov.
- President Yeltsin and the Chechen leader Aslan Maskhadov could meet within a week's time but it is not clear what the outcome of such a meeting may be.
- Russian banks seem to be using the name of prominent financier George Soros as a weapon of preference in their information war.
- Turkmenistan will be able to use Russian pipelines for its gas deliveries to CIS countries but it is Gazprom that will set the price strategy.
- Gazprom is not satisfied with the way its shares are traded in Russia and their price levels on the market.
- The Bank of Latvia says Russian-Latvian economic relations could worsen after tax police in St Petersburg froze correspondent's accounts of a number of Baltic banks.
- Procter & Gamble is to restructure its operations at the Novomoskovskbytkhim detergent plant south of Moscow.
- Russian automaker GAZ has started selling its cars and trucks on credit.
- The forthcoming redenomination of the rouble has prompted an investment boom on the market.
- Tatarstan President Mintimer Shaimiyev has sanctioned the construction of a big oil refinery in his republic.
SEVODNYA
- Defence Minister Igor Sergeyev admitted that the army was very near the brink but the situation has started to stabilise.
- The space crew due to replace cosmonauts at Mir station have successfully docked with the crippled space craft but the main work lies ahead.
- An unremitting energy crisis continues to pester the people and industries of Russia's Far East.
- Alfa-group which has a controlling stake in the Tyumen oil company is likely to appoint outside management at its subsidiary Nizhnevartovskneftegaz.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin is likely to insist in his efforts to reverse the results of the Norilsk Nickel auction.
- Redenomination of the currency in Russia should be coupled with thorough economic reform if it is to yield fruit.
- China does not seem to be ready to come to terms with Russia over the border delimitation in the Far East.
- Persistance by both sides over minor technicalities in the delimitation of the border between Russia and Estonia testify to major political disagreement between the two countries.
IZVESTIA
- Russian and Turkmen presidents have reached a compromise over a complex problem with gas deliveries to foreign countries.
- The new director of Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Smelter, who is apparently an Orthodox believer, has consecrated the factory which has recently been the scene of bloody conflicts.
- Despite limited domestic military production, Belarus has joined the world's top 10 arms exporters, the paper says.
ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA
- Prices will not rise dramatically in 1998 and they will not be linked to the rouble re-denomination, Sergei Dubinin, the head of Russia's Central Bank, says.
- Russian military officials do not want to reveal how many generals are in the army, a figure which is to be reduced significantly in military reforms.
ROSSIISKIYE VESTI
- Scandals around recent privatisation sell-offs have shown honour and professional ethics have fallen in Russia.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- Instead of begging for international loans, the Russian government should clear up domestic banking problems, the paper suggests, analysing the situation with Russia's foreign debts.
--Andrei Shukshin, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
